ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said it is too early to talk with China over trade and he does not want China to have a difficult time due to trade. In regards to EU, he said he is having a successful conversation with the continent over trade. NEC Director Kudlow said trade deal with China is not imminent. (Newswires)

UK

UK is to plan to compromise on Irish border to get a Brexit deal, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK lawmaker and Brexit hardliner Rees-Mogg said changing a leadership usually causes more problems than it solves, it's prudent to back PM May. (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Hammond said if WTO regulations are implemented we will have to have border checks, while he added we need a very very gradual process of re-balancing our trade with the EU. (Newswires)

UK Brexit Minister Raab said the government is not even considering a second referendum, while he added UK PM May’s goal after the Salzburg Summit is to not see a border down the Irish Sea. Earlier, Raab stated EU must get serious and that the EU approach is one sided and allows no scope for compromise. (Newswires)


EU

Italian Finance Minister Tria said a 2.4% deficit-GDP target is not in line with EU rules, but it does have precedence. Tria also noted that the EU can be calm over Italian budget proposals (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Di Maio said EU's Moscovici spoke out against Italy budget plan to "upset markets" and there is no reason to question 2019 2.4% budget deficit-GDP target, while Deputy PM Salvini said Genoa decree could increase deficit. (Newswires/ANSA)

EU Commission President Juncker said, on Italy's 2019 budget proposal, we are in talks, let's see where they end and if they want further special treatment it would end Euro. (Newswires)

EU Commission VP Dombrovkis said the initial assessment of Italian budget is that it is not compatible with the stability and growth pact. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Rosengren (Hawkish, Non-voter) said FOMC should continue on its current pace of raising rates, and the further the US gets below full employment the higher the risk of inflation increasing. He said the continued growth and tighter labour markets will likely lead to imbalances including but not limited to inflation, while strong growth is expected to continue for now, though trade and emerging markets problems pose risks. (Newswires)

Fed's Williams (Neutral, Voter) said as we move towards a more normal conduct of policy, we shouldn't rest easy and think we won’t run into future challenges. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Dove, Non-voter) said so far tax cuts have not boosted business spending outside of the oil sector, we are probably not at full employment. He added the he sees no reason to move rates up yet and tap the brakes, economic indicators are flashing green but the bond market is flashing yellow. In regards to NAFTA, he said he is not seeing any near-term effects from the tariffs but could be damaging in the long term and NAFTA has been a huge help to the US economy. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) said it is now or never to build economic union. (Newswires)

Argentinian Central Bank sets LELIQ rate at 67.18%. (Newswires) Note: This follows source reports on Friday that the Argentinian central bank are reportedly set to raise their LELIQ rate from 60% to 65%.

COMMODITIES

Iran to start offering oil via stock exchange as soon as next week, as according to a senior source. (Newswires)

OPEC survey stated that September output rose 90k BPD MM to 32.85mln (a high for the year) on increased Libyan supply. (Newswires)

Aluminium premiums for October-December in Japan are down 22% Q/Q set at USD103/T; according to sources. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump said he expects to sign the new USMCA deal by the end of November. US White House Advisor Navarro mentioned November 30th, while Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo stated that the new USMCA could be signed by the three Presidents at the G20 on November 29th. Guajardo also said that the new US-Mexico-Canada trade deal could take effect from the second half of 2019. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said the new trilateral trade deal removes uncertainty for manufacturers and investors and noted NAFTA is not a 'finish line' as it still needs ratification. Trudeau added the new deal will bring US and Canada even closer together and the US side has expressed willingness to discuss steel and aluminium tariffs. (Newswires)

US President Trump said steel and aluminium tariffs will remain on Canada and Mexico unless they can do something like quotas, while USTR Ligthizer and US Commerce Secretary Ross said there is no deadline for resolving metals tariff dispute. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

* SPX +0.37% at 2925, NDX +0.23% at 7645, DJI +0.73% at 26652 SECTORS: Energy +1.47%, Materials +1.04%, Industrials +0.90%, Cons Discretionary -0.20%, Cons Staples -0.06%, Healthcare +0.54%, Financials +0.35%, Tech +0.49%, Telecoms -0.11%, Utilities -0.30%.

Tesla (TSLA) was one of the day’s biggest movers, paring back previous losses, following Elon Musk settling his lawsuit with the SEC. General Electric (GE) was another big gainer following Larry Culp’s appointment to CEO. Praxair (PX) benefitted from Chinese regulatory approval of its merger with Linde AG (LIN GY). DaVita (DVA) pushed higher following a veto on a senate bill working in its favour and so did Marathon Petroleum (MPC), leading energy sector gains on the back of higher oil prices. Intel (INTC) was one of the day’s losers after a downgrade at Barclays, citing a costly battle to maintain market share. Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) was down on a negative report from Plainview. F5 Networks (FFIV) pushed lower after a downgrade at Piper Jaffray. Broadcasters, including Viacom (VIAB) and CBS (CBS), also were part of the day’s biggest losers. Automakers strength attributed to USMCA trade deal.

The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Monday, falling after overnight news of a free trade deal in principle between US, Mexico and Canada. A slight easing in Italian budget tensions was also cited for the bund sell-off in early European trade, which Tsys sympathised with. 2-year yields edging up slightly, while longer-dated yields rose by as much as c.4bps at settlement. Major curve spreads also widened modestly (2s5s up 0.3bps, 2s30s wider by around 2.5bps, struggling to maintain ground above their 50DMAs, technicians observed). US T-note futures (Z8) settles 3+ ticks lower at 118-21+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 1st October 2018 - Trump says tariffs to remain despite USMCA and too soon for China trade talks
content:

To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.
 

US MARKET WRAP – 1 October 2018:  Trump says tariffs to remain despite USMCA and too soon for China trade talks

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, crude up, dollar up.
* REAR-VIEW: Trump expects USMCA to be signed in November & too soon for China trade talks, PM May to compromise with EU on Irish border, US ISM Mfg miss, Fed’s Kashkari, Rosengren & Williams earn over trade and EMs.

* AHEAD: RBA Interest Rate Decision, UK Construction PMI, Fed's Powell to speak.

 

* USMCA: US President Trump held a conference on the new trade deal with Canada and Mexico where he announced to expect to sign the new trilateral deal by the end of November; he announced all three parties have agreed on labour, IP and environmental provisions and proclaimed steel and aluminium tariffs will remain on Canada and Mexico unless they can do something like quotas; US Commerce Secretary Ross echoing Trump said there is no timeline to remove metal tariffs on Canada and Mexico. White House Advisor Navarro also commented saying the new trade deal should be signed on November 30th whilst Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo sees it taking effect from the second half of 2019. Mexico’s Foreign Minister said it would be positive to solve the ongoing dispute over steel and aluminium tariffs before the new deal is signed and added the new trilateral NAFTA should be able to be signed by President Pena Niento. On the Canada side, PM Trudeau noted how the new deal is still not a “finish line”, stressing that Canada had to make the hardest compromises of the three parties.

* TRADE: US President Trump, at the USMCA conference, touched on China noting it is too early to engage in trade talks with the region, emphasizing he does not want China to have a difficult time due to trade. White House Advisor Kudlow added a trade deal with China is not imminent. Trump, nonetheless, appeared upbeat on the trade relationship with the EU as he reported having a successful conversation over trade; on the subject, UK Finance Minister Hammond urged a “very very” gradual process of re-balancing trade with the EU, adding that if the WTO regulations are implemented we will have to have border checks.

* ITALY: On Monday the EU has responded to Italy’s decision to set a deficit of 2.4%, as agreed by the government last week, as sources reported the EU Commission are set to reject Italian budget plans. EU Commission VP Dombrovskis commented that Italy's budget is not compatible with the stability pact, whilst EU Commission President Juncker stated ‘let's see where they end’ and noted that if they want a further special treatment it would end the Euro’. In response, Italian Economy Minister Tria said there will be no end to the Euro noting the EU can be calm over the Italian budget proposals; he added a 2.4% deficit-GDP target is not in line with EU rules, but it does have precedence. Also, Deputy PM Di Maio said EU's Moscovici spoke out against Italy’s budget plan to "upset markets" and there is no reason to question the 2019 2.4% budget deficit-GDP target.

* FED: Fed's Kashkari (Dove, Non-Voter) sees no reason to move rates up yet and tap the brakes since economic indicators are flashing green; he however warned the bond market is flashing yellow. Regarding trade, he is not seeing any near-term effects from the tariffs but believes it could be damaging in the long term, noting NAFTA has been a huge help to the US economy. He thinks the economy is probably not at full employment and warned of elevated recession risk currently citing trade wars, emerging markets and Fed hiking as downside risks. Fed's Rosengren said the FOMC should continue its current pace of raising rates and that hikes should continue to a "mildly restrictive" level to avoid need for faster rate increases later; he noted the further the US gets below full employment the higher the risk of inflation increasing. He also said continued growth and tighter labour markets will likely lead to imbalances including, but not limited to inflation. He expects strong growth to continue for now, though trade and emerging markets pose risks. Finally, Fed's Williams reiterated data-dependency and warned we shouldn't rest easy and think we won’t run into future challenges as the Fed moves towards a more normal conduct of policy.

* BREXIT: UK lawmaker and Brexit hardliner Rees-Mogg stated it is prudent to back PM May noting that changing a leadership usually causes more problems than it solves. Rees-Mogg, an influential figure head of the ERG euro-sceptic think tank, has seemingly hinted that May could be secure in her position. Elsewhere, sources reported the UK is to plan to compromise on Irish border, to get a Brexit deal done; PM May therefore seems open to make a new Brexit offer to the EU on a major sticking point to unlock negotiations. Alongside this, Brexit Secretary Raab urged the EU to get serious, as he sees the EU approach to be one sided and allows no scope for compromise whilst UK Chancellor Hammond commenting on PM May's Chequers plan said it is a middle of the road choice, and is confident that the UK has the fiscal capacity to support a no-deal. Moreover, he noted the choice in November will be on the deal or no deal and that should focus minds and reiterated the government is not even considering a second referendum.

* US ISM MANUFACURING: The ISM manufacturing headline fell to 59.8 in September below the 60.0 consensus, from a prior 61.3. Analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics said the print signalled a strong manufacturing sector. “August’s 14-year high always looked a bit suspicious, it appeared to be supported by favourable seasonals, so at some point a correction was always on the cards.” On the new orders sub-index, Pantheon said while it fell by over 3 points, it was still high by historical standards. “The ISM responds to higher long-term interest rates with a long lag,” Pantheon said, “but eventually it will be weighed down by the Fed’s hiking actions. For now, they believe the manufacturing sector is strong even though they expect the trade deficit will keep widening; they note the figure is consistent with output growth of only about 2% slower than the rate of growth of domestic demand.

* SPX +0.37% at 2925, NDX +0.23% at 7645, DJI +0.73% at 26652 SECTORS: Energy +1.47%, Materials +1.04%, Industrials +0.90%, Cons Discretionary -0.20%, Cons Staples -0.06%, Healthcare +0.54%, Financials +0.35%, Tech +0.49%, Telecoms -0.11%, Utilities -0.30%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Tesla (TSLA) was one of the day’s biggest movers, paring back previous losses, following Elon Musk settling his lawsuit with the SEC. General Electric (GE) was another big gainer following Larry Culp’s appointment to CEO. Praxair (PX) benefitted from Chinese regulatory approval of its merger with Linde AG (LIN GY). DaVita (DVA) pushed higher following a veto on a senate bill working in its favour and so did Marathon Petroleum (MPC), leading energy sector gains on the back of higher oil prices. Intel (INTC) was one of the day’s losers after a downgrade at Barclays, citing a costly battle to maintain market share. Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) was down on a negative report from Plainview. F5 Networks (FFIV) pushed lower after a downgrade at Piper Jaffray. Broadcasters, including Viacom (VIAB) and CBS (CBS), also were part of the day’s biggest losers. Automakers strength attributed to USMCA trade deal.

* WTI (X8) SETTLES $2.05 HIGHER AT $75.30 , BRENT (V8) SETTLES $2.25 HIGHER AT $84.98. Crude traded higher on Monday, with Brent trading above $85/bbl for the first time since November 2014, with traders re-focussing on the Iranian crude production and exportation ahead of the US re-applying sanctions on the nation's oil sector in November. "Estimates vary of course, but a Bloomberg survey has Iranian production declining 140,000 bpd to 3.36 mmbpd and exports falling 229,000 bpd to 1.60 mmbpd," Citi's analysts said, though points out that in spite of that decline and the further downtrend in Venezuelan output, OPEC total production still edged higher during September. "In our view this contrast fully highlights the extent to which the support for prices stems from the anticipation of future tightness rather than a current shortfall in supply," Citi adds. Iran's oil minister on Monday said the nation has no intention to cut oil production or exports. Elsewhere, Iraq's southern oil exports were said to be running at a clip of 3.56mln BPD in September, slightly lower than August levels.

US T-NOTE FUTURES Z8) SETTLES 3+ TICKS LOWER AT 118-21+. The Treasury curve bear-steepened on Monday, falling after overnight news of a free trade deal in principle between US, Mexico and Canada. A slight easing in Italian budget tensions was also cited for the bund sell-off in early European trade, which Tsys sympathised with. 2-year yields edging up slightly, while longer-dated yields rose by as much as c.4bps at settlement. Major curve spreads also widened modestly (2s5s up 0.3bps, 2s30s wider by around 2.5bps, struggling to maintain ground above their 50DMAs, technicians observed).

*  CAD, MXN: Still holding their bulk of its USMCA gains, albeit off best levels vs the Usd after pulling up short of resistance around 1.2765 and 18.5000 respectively to trade back below 1.2800 and close to 18.7000. The Loonie may have been undermined by a Canadian manufacturing PMI miss along with some consolidation/profit taking, while the Mxn was dictated by more commentary on the new NAFTA agreement from US President Trump, Canadian PM Trudeau and Mexican Foreign & Economy Ministers.

* GBP: The Pound derived some Brexit related momentum to bounce from near 1.3000 lows vs the Dollar where stops were lurking to briefly trade above 1.3100 on reports that the UK may be considering an Irish border compromise on customs to facilitate a deal with the EU. Cable is currently around 1.3050, with little lasting benefit from a stronger than expected UK PMI. 

* JPY, CHF: Still the noted G10 laggards, as Usd/Jpy extended its recent rally and range break trend just beyond 114.00 following dips in Japan’s Q3 Tankan survey and September manufacturing PMI, while Usd/Chf remains within 0.9845-00 parameters in wake of a less robust Swiss manufacturing PMI that overshadowed a recovery in retail sales.

* EUR: Was anchored around 1.1600 for most of the session after somewhat mixed Eurozone manufacturing PMIs and reports suggesting that the EU will formally reject Italy’s proposed 2.4% 2019 deficit (in November, according to sources). It then slipped below the figure to consolidate around 1.1580 on more negative EU response on Italy.

NZD, AUD: Ending Monday’s EU session pretty much where they started and all close to parity vs the Usd, UsdNzd just kept afloat of 0.6600 and 0.7200 respectively following a weaker than expected Chinese Caixin manufacturing PMI overnight (50.0) and comments from White House advisor Kudlow noting that a trade agreement with China is not in the offing. Ahead, the Kiwi eyes NZIER Q3 confidence and cap u later, and the Aud awaits the RBA on Tuesday.

* EM: The Lira is heading the regional pack, with Usd/Try seeing a more convincing break below the 6.0000 handle as improved Turkish trade data (albeit on a hefty jump in exports) offset a disappointing manufacturing PMI (deeper in contraction territory).

Cable is currently around 1.3075, with little lasting benefit from a stronger than expected UK PMI.  

JPY/CHF  

Still the noted G10 laggards, as Usd/Jpy extended its recent rally and range break trend just beyond 114.00 following dips in Japan’s Q3 Tankan survey and September manufacturing PMI, while Usd/Chf remains within 0.9845-00 parameters in wake of a less robust Swiss manufacturing PMI that overshadowed a recovery in retail sales.

EUR/NZD/AUD

Ending Monday’s EU session pretty much where they started and all close to parity vs the Usd, as the single currency remains anchored around 1.1600 after somewhat mixed Eurozone manufacturing PMIs and reports suggesting that the EU will formally reject Italy’s proposed 2.4% 2019 deficit (in November, according to sources). Note, Italian Finance Minister Tria attempted to placate markets and investors by calling for calm and promising to explain next year’s budget plan, but EC VP Dombrovskis maintained that the plan violates the bloc’s stability pact. Meanwhile, the antipodean Dollars only just kept afloat of 0.6600 and 0.7200 respectively following a weaker than expected Chinese Caixin manufacturing PMI overnight (50.0) and comments from White House advisor Kudlow noting that a trade agreement with China is not in the offing. Ahead, the Kiwi eyes NZIER Q3 confidence and cap u later, and the Aud awaits the RBA on Tuesday.

EM

The Lira is heading the regional pack, with Usd/Try seeing a more convincing break below the 6.0000 handle as improved Turkish trade data (albeit on a hefty jump in exports) offset a disappointing manufacturing PMI (deeper in contraction territory).

(Newswires)
  • Of note for Hasbro (HAS), Barron’s writes this week that the recent liquidation of Toys ‘R’ Us is a temporary set-back for the toy co. but growth is expected to resume in 2019 as it firms its name as a diversified entertainment co. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

(Newswires)
  • Comcast (CMCSA) – The broadcaster has said it will pause its share repurchase programme in 2019 to reduce the amount of debt it will incur in its acquisition of Sky (SKY LN). Separately, the co. and Charter (CHTR) have been struggling to sell their minority stake in the New York Mets, valued at approximately USD 250mln. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – In the wake of the 50mln user accounts breach, the social media giant is facing repercussions. An EU privacy watchdog could sue Facebook up to USD 1.63bln and a user group in California has filed a class action complaint whilst a German watchdog was ‘very optimistic’ his office would take action after the data privacy scandal. (Newswires)

There remains plenty of pessimism on the co. where Barron’s highlighted its industry-relative high valuation. There has also been comments in Reuters suggesting the fine could fuel investors to file lawsuits as it has given them confidence that the co. has done wrongdoing to shareholders and a WSJ article reporting uncertainty is straining the co. now. Elsewhere, Musk tweeted that the co. is “close to profitability.” (Newswires)

subject: UK is to plan to compromise on Irish border to get a Brexit deal, according to sources
analysis_details:
Earlier we reported comments from ITV's Peston that the government's current thinking on Brexit is as follows: 

1: In the Northern Ireland protocol or backstop, the government is prepared to allow checks on conformity to EU standards on goods flowing from GB to Northern Ireland - so long as consent obtained from DUP and Sinn Fein

2: PM would only “chuck Chequers” if EU was crystal clear it prefers Canada-style FTA. She does not think they will try to force her in that direction but cannot rule out. They have only days to do this.

3: If she get a Brexit deal with EU, she will move fast to publish an assessment of it, then have five days of Commons debate, to precede the promised meaningful vote by MPs.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 1st October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US-Canada-Mexico agreed to new NAFTA named the USMCA; CAD and MXN the major outperformers in FX
  • FTSE MIB the outperforming bourse as Italy sees some reprieve
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US mfg PMIs, US construction spending, ISM mfg PMI, Fed’s Bostic, Kashkari, Rosengren, BoE’s Tenreyro

NAFTA

US and Canada said in an official statement that they have reached a trade deal with Mexico in an agreement dubbed the USMCA (US-Mexico-Canada Agreement). US President Trump is to sign the new trade agreement by the end of November, which will then get passed on to Congress.

Canada has agreed to eliminate the "Class 7" milk protein pricing system and increase US access to Canada's dairy market beyond Trans-Pacific partnership levels. The New trade deal does not make major changes to current Chapter 19 trade dispute settlement mechanism which gives the three countries the right to challenge each other’s anti-dumping and countervailing duty decisions in front of an expert panel with members from both countries involved in a dispute. US said the trade deal with Canada does not affect US steel and aluminium tariffs currently levied on Canada, and that these tariffs are separate to the trilateral deal. A Senior Trump Administration official said if Trump imposes auto tariffs, both Mexico and Canada will be accommodated in "side letters".

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mixed following a rather uneventful lead from Wall St. on Friday where major bourses ended the day little changed as markets wrapped up a strong quarter where the S&P showed it best quarterly gain since Q4 2013. ASX 200 (-0.6%) underperformed amid a slowdown in China’s manufacturing sector shown by the Caixin data, while Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) was buoyed on currency effect in a continued weakness of the JPY following a downbeat Tankan release and Manufacturing PMI. Elsewhere, Hong Kong and Mainland China are closed today due to public holidays.

Indonesia’s island Sulawesi was hit by a 7.5 magnitude earthquake, which triggered a 6m (20ft) tsunami that hit the cities of Palu and Donggala. Officials have confirmed the death toll rose to over 800.  (BBC/Sky News/CNN)

China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi said protectionism will only hurt one's self and unilateral moves will bring damage to all, and China won’t be blackmailed or succumbed to pressure over trade. (Newswires)

China reportedly cancelled high-level security talks with the US. (NY Times)

PBoC said the yuan exchange rate and market expectations are generally stable. (Newswires)

China Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 50.0 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 50.6) (Newswires)

China NBS Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 50.8 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 51.3)

China NBS Non-Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 54.9 (Prev. 54.2)

Japanese Tankan Big Manufacturing Index (Q3) 19.0 vs. Exp. 22.0 (Prev. 21.0) (Newswires)
Japanese Tankan All Big Industry Capex (Q3) 13.4% vs. Exp. 14.2% (Prev. 13.6%)

Japan Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 52.5 vs. Exp. 52.9 (Prev. 52.9)

EU/UK/US

UK PM May said the Chequers plan is not dead, while added she is prepared to listen to EU counter-proposals but she wants to hear the details of EU’s concerns, and EU leaders want a deal just as she does. She said she believes Chequers will not destroy the single market and a Canada-style deal is not on the table for EU. In the interview, she refused to answer whether a no-deal Brexit will mean a hard border in Ireland. Note: BBC’s Andrew Marr noted a no-deal under WTO would result in a hard border. (BBC)

UK PM May, in a Sunday Times interview, told Tory rebels to “stop playing politics” and the only proposal on the table at the moment that delivers, is the Chequers plan, while she reiterated that no deal is better than a bad deal but she thought a good deal could be reached. She also challenged the EU to come forward with a counter proposal. (BBC/Times/Sun)

Former UK Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has refused to rule out a leadership challenge to UK PM May. Furthermore, in an interview with The Sunday Times, Johnson questioned whether UK PM May believes in Brexit and branded her Chequers plan “deranged”. (BBC/Times)

EU’s Chief Negotiator Barnier told Labour leader Corbyn that they believed they might be close to finding agreement with UK PM May, but everyone is needs to act calmly and responsibly if the agreement was to get through parliament. (Guardian)

UK Labour leader Corbyn was told his stance made a no-deal Brexit more likely than not; according to sources in Brussels. Brussels is said to hope for the Tory conference to break the deal deadlock. (Newswires)

UK’s Labour party claims UK PM May’s government is the “most divided ever” as it releases a dossier of over 100 Tory MPs criticising the government or colleagues. (Independent)

UK Brexit Secretary Raab is set to warn that if the EU tries to force the UK into accepting a customs union then it will leave without a deal. (BBC)

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt has warned the EU that it will stir Britain's “Dunkirk spirit” if it tries to force a bad Brexit deal on the UK. (Telegraph)

UK Business Secretary Clark has said there are “grounds for optimism” that UK will strike a Brexit deal with the EU. (Sky News)

UK Brexit Secretary Raab says the EU must get serious, and that the EU approach is one sided and allows no scope for compromise. (Newswires)

EU Commissioner Dombrovskis said what emerges so far from discussions in Italy does not seem to be in line with EU fiscal rules, he added it's important to stick to responsible fiscal policy to keep interest rates low. The Dutch PM has also expressed his concerns over the Italian budget plan. (Newswires)

Italian Finance Minister Tria is attempting to head off a confrontation between the EU and Italy that by insisting that the country will reduce public debt despite its plans to increase spending. (FT)

EU Commission are set to reject Italian budget plans, as according to EU sources. (Newswires)

Italy's EU Affairs Minister Savona says there has been no discussion on the EUR. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 53.8 vs. Exp. 52.6 (Prev. 52.8, Rev. 53.0)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Sep) 53.2 vs. Exp. 53.3 (Prev. 53.3)

German Markit/BME Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 53.7 vs. Exp. 53.7 (Prev. 53.7)

French Markit Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 52.5 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.5)

Italian Markit/ADACI Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 50.0 vs. Exp. 50.3 (Prev. 50.1)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea’s Foreign Minister announced that North Korea would not take the first steps towards denuclearisation without further guarantees from the US. He also warned of the increasing mistrust between Pyongyang and Washington DC. (Telegraph)

Russian Foreign Affairs Minister Lavrov said everything possible will be done to preserve Iran nuclear deal. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB’s Rehn (Neutral) said interest rates will remain at this low at least until summer 2019. (Newswires

EQUITIES

European equities have started the day on the front foot, with the FTSE the laggard, as a slightly bid GBP is weighing on the index. The consumer discretionary sector is the marked underperformer as RyanAir (-8.7%) cutting guidance due to lower than expected Q2 and Q3 traffic has hit European airline stocks, with all of Air France (-2.5%), EasyJet (-3.0%) and Lufthansa (-1.0%) in the red.

Linde (+1.2%) is leading the gains in Germany and has supported the DAX to near the top of the index pile after receiving antitrust approval from China for their Praxair merger. The FTSE MIB is the outperforming index as Italian stocks are seeing some reprieve from last week’s sell off. Index heavyweight Telecom Italia (-1.5%) are, however, in the red after a broker downgrade at Barclays.

FX

CAD - The Loonie has leapt to the top of the G10 leader board, and aside from testing resistance round 1.2800 vs its US counterpart that Cad is bid and outperforming right across the board. The clear catalyst is a somewhat unexpected pre-‘deadline’ deal between the US and Canada on a new style NAFTA deal that will include Mexico and be renamed as USMCA. Looking at technicals, if Usd/Cad breaches 1.2800 and remains below multi-month chart support around 1.2813-19, that includes a 50% Fib, nearest or next downside targets are seen circa 1.2730, 1.2685 and even 1.2500, while from a more fundamental perspective comments from BoC’s Lane later may impact.

GBP - Another relatively firm major currency, as Cable inches up over 1.3050 and Eur/Gbp retreats from just above 0.8900 on the back of a considerably firmer than forecast UK manufacturing PMI, which goes some way towards offsetting more Brexit deal jitters mixed with cautious optimism ahead of the crucial weeks of negotiation before ‘deadlines’ to strike an arrangement between the UK and EU.

JPY/CHF - The clear underperformers, as Usd/Jpy continues to break higher and just climbed above 114.00 following dips in Japan’s Q3 Tankan survey and September manufacturing PMI, while Usd/Chf remains within 0.9845-00 parameters in wake of a less robust Swiss manufacturing PMI that overshadowed a recovery in retail sales.

EUR/NZD/AUD - All relatively flat or narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with the single currency pivoting 1.1600 amidst somewhat divergent Eurozone manufacturing PMIs and reports suggesting that the EU will register its objection to Italy’s proposed 2.4% 2019 budget (in November, according to sources). Note also, the spill-over from SOMA may well weigh on the headline pair at some stage. Meanwhile, the antipodean Dollars are just holding above 0.6600 and 0.7200 respectively following a weaker than expected Chinese Caixin manufacturing PMI overnight (50.0), as the Kiwi eyes NZIER Q3 confidence and cap u tonight, and the Aud awaits the RBA on Tuesday. 

EM - The Peso and Lira are heading the regional pack, with Usd/Mxn testing bids around 18.5000 on the aforementioned NAFTA breakthrough to include all 3 countries in a new pact, while Usd/Try has made a more convincing break below the 6.0000 handle as healthy or at least encouraging Turkish trade data offset a disappointing manufacturing PMI (former boosted by exports vs latter deeper in sub-50 territory).

FIXED INCOME

Italian bonds have maintained their recovery momentum to trade in positive territory for the first time since the open and almost touching 124.00 at 123.97 vs last Friday’s 123.84 close and a low of 122.80. No obvious fundamental reason for the more sustained rebound, but the 10 year benchmark has lost a lot of ground since the 2.4% deficit was announced and in truth the EC’s damning verdict is hardly a surprise given comments from Brussels in response to developments unfolding in Rome.  Consequently, Bunds have recoiled further from best levels and through the next line of chart support around 158.50 to test the resolve of the 158.40 level (158.37 low, -42 ticks vs +11 ticks at one stage), and with 158.24 next on the radar if stops are tripped. Elsewhere, Gilts recently receded to 120.66, -28 ticks vs +5 ticks at the Liffe pinnacle, and US Treasuries have declined further amidst more pronounced curve steepening as the 10 year contract eyes tech support at 118-16+.         

COMMODITIES

The oil market is uneventful this morning and seeing a lack of newsflow for the fossil fuel, with Brent essentially unchanged for the day and hanging just below the USD 83.00 handle after last week’s rise to over 4 year highs.

A senior Iranian Oil Official said they have no plans to reduce oil production.

Most metals are in the red this morning with zinc and copper down by over 1% and gold down by 0.5% as the week-long holiday in China is hitting demand.

content: A relatively choppy start to Q4 for the 10 year German benchmark amidst somewhat mixed external impulses, as softer US Treasuries on the back of a broad upturn in risk sentiment due to the NAFTA breakthrough are counterbalanced by another decline in Italian bonds following reports that the EC will officially reject the 2019 budget proposal after formal review next month. Hence, Bunds have traded either side of last Friday’s 158.79 closing level within a 158.69-87 range and keeping tabs on BTPs that are trying consolidate off 122.97 lows. Ahead, Eurozone manufacturing PMIs may offer a distraction, but unlikely as events in Rome continue to dominate proceedings and dictate direction in the region.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

10th October 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mixed following a rather uneventful lead from Wall St. on Friday where major bourses ended the day little changed as markets wrapped up a strong quarter where the S&P showed it best quarterly gain since Q4 2013. ASX 200 (-0.6%) underperformed amid a slowdown in China’s manufacturing sector shown by the Caixin data, while Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) was buoyed on currency effect in a continued weakness of the JPY following a downbeat Tankan release and Manufacturing PMI. Elsewhere, Hong Kong and Mainland China are closed today due to public holidays.

FTSE

Rio Tinto (RIO LN) – The co. has approved a USD 1.55bln investment in the Australian Iron projects in Pilbara, with the aim of maintaining capacity. (Newswires)

BHP Biliton (BLT LN) – the co. has approved the sale of its onshore US assets at Fayetteville, no financial details were disclosed. (Newswires)

Melrose (MRO LN) – The co. are considering the sale of Nortek for GBP 6bln, just two years after they purchased the co. for GBB 2.2bln as according to sources. (Telegraph)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – The Anglo-Dutch co. alongside Mitsubishi, Petroliam, PetroChina and Kora Gas have agreed to a USD 31bln project to carve out the fastest route for gas from North America to Asia. The project is set to be Canada’s largest infrastructure project ever. (Newswires)

BT (BT/A LN) – the co. has completed the OFCOM mandated transfer of 31k employees to Openreach, completing the largest staff transfer in history. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

EASYJET (EZJ LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM AT BERNSTEIN

BARCLAYS (BARC LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

DAX

Allianz (ALV GY) – The co.’s CFO has said that FY2018 is going well, and earnings are in line with previous quarters. (Newswires)

German Banks – The German financial regulator is concerned about the high levels of lending banks are conducting, and may soon require them to build extra capital reserves, as according to sources. (Handelsblatt)

BMW (BMW GY) – The co.’s association of independent car dealerships has advised its members to sign new long-term contracts with the automotive co. before the month-end deadline, avoiding car sale and spare part disruptions. (Newswires)

Linde (LIN GY) – The co. has received approval from Chinese antitrust authorities for its proposed merger with Praxair. (Newswires)

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – the co. is set to hold an analyst call today after they agreed on Sunday to split into two and appointed Kerhoff as the new CEO on a 5 year contract. The co. also named a new Chairman, Pellens, and has ended the long-standing leadership void in the co. ever since Heisinger quit. The co.’s CEO on Monday said that they have “unanimous support” for their new strategy.  (Newswires)

CAC

French Automotive Names - French Car Registrations -12.83%, Peugeot (UG FP) +2.57%, Renault (RNO FP) -17.81%. (Newswires)

LVMH (MC FP) – The co. is pushing Celine as their new “star performer”, under the guidance of Hedi Slimane. This comes after the designer cline gave the brand a makeover at its debut in Paris fashion week. (Newswires)

Veolia (VIE FP) – The co. has agreed to sell their 30% stake in Transdev to Rethmann, as according to sources. (Le Figaro)

Sanofi (SAN FP) – The co. has said that Libtayo, the skin cancer treatment has been approved by the US FDA. Elsewhere the co. have offloaded Zentiva to Advent in a EUR 1.9Bln deal. (Newswires)

Scor (SCR FP) – A longtime investor in the co. has said that they were right to ignore a takeover approach from Covea. Amber Capital, the investor, has said that any potential approach should only be considered at EUR 50/share, not at the EUR 43/share that was offered. (FT)

Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas (FCC SM) – The co. has closed the sale of its minority holding in Aqualia to ISM for EUR 1.02bln. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

BROKER MOVES

ANHEUSER-BUSCH INBEV (ABI BB) DOWNGARDED TO HOLD FROM BUT AT JEFFRIES

TELECOM ITALIA (TIT IM) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – the co. has received approval for Xolair from the US FDA. (Newswires)

US

subject: EU Commission are set to reject Italian budget plans, as according to EU sources
RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 1st October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • US and Canada said in an official statement that they have reached a trade deal with Mexico in an agreement dubbed the USMCA (US-Mexico-Canada Agreement)
  • Asian stocks traded mixed following a rather uneventful lead from Wall St. on Friday. Hong Kong and Mainland China closed due to public holidays
  • In FX, focus has been on JPY weakness and CAD strength with the latter hitting 4-month highs vs. USD
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ, UK and US mfg PMIs, US construction spending, ISM mfg PMI, Fed’s Bostic, Kashkari, Rosengren, BoE’s Tenreyro

NAFTA

US and Canada said in an official statement that they have reached a trade deal with Mexico in an agreement dubbed the USMCA (US-Mexico-Canada Agreement). US President Trump is to sign the new trade agreement by the end of November, which will then get passed on to Congress.

Canada has agreed to eliminate the "Class 7" milk protein pricing system and increase US access to Canada's dairy market beyond Trans-Pacific partnership levels. The New trade deal does not make major changes to current Chapter 19 trade dispute settlement mechanism which gives the three countries the right to challenge each other’s anti-dumping and countervailing duty decisions in front of an expert panel with members from both countries involved in a dispute. US said the trade deal with Canada does not affect US steel and aluminium tariffs currently levied on Canada, and that these tariffs are separate to the trilateral deal. A Senior Trump Administration official said if Trump imposes auto tariffs, both Mexico and Canada will be accommodated in "side letters".

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded mixed following a rather uneventful lead from Wall St. on Friday where major bourses ended the day little changed as markets wrapped up a strong quarter where the S&P showed it best quarterly gain since Q4 2013. ASX 200 (-0.6%) underperformed amid a slowdown in China’s manufacturing sector shown by the Caixin data, while Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) was buoyed on currency effect in a continued weakness of the JPY following a downbeat Tankan release and Manufacturing PMI. Elsewhere, Hong Kong and Mainland China are closed today due to public holidays.

Indonesia’s island Sulawesi was hit by a 7.5 magnitude earthquake, which triggered a 6m (20ft) tsunami that hit the cities of Palu and Donggala. Officials have confirmed the death toll rose to over 800.  (BBC/Sky News/CNN)

China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi said protectionism will only hurt one's self and unilateral moves will bring damage to all, and China won’t be blackmailed or succumbed to pressure over trade. (Newswires)

China reportedly cancelled high-level security talks with the US. (NY Times)

PBoC said the yuan exchange rate and market expectations are generally stable. (Newswires)

China Caixin Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 50.0 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 50.6) (Newswires)

China NBS Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 50.8 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 51.3)

China NBS Non-Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 54.9 (Prev. 54.2)

Japanese Tankan Big Manufacturing Index (Q3) 19.0 vs. Exp. 22.0 (Prev. 21.0) (Newswires)
Japanese Tankan All Big Industry Capex (Q3) 13.4% vs. Exp. 14.2% (Prev. 13.6%)

Japan Manufacturing PMI (Sep) 52.5 vs. Exp. 52.9 (Prev. 52.9)


UK

UK PM May said the Chequers plan is not dead, while added she is prepared to listen to EU counter-proposals but she wants to hear the details of EU’s concerns, and EU leaders want a deal just as she does. She said she believes Chequers will not destroy the single market and a Canada-style deal is not on the table for EU. In the interview, she refused to answer whether a no-deal Brexit will mean a hard border in Ireland. Note: BBC’s Andrew Marr noted a no-deal under WTO would result in a hard border. (BBC)

UK PM May, in a Sunday Times interview, told Tory rebels to “stop playing politics” and the only proposal on the table at the moment that delivers, is the Chequers plan, while she reiterated that no deal is better than a bad deal but she thought a good deal could be reached. She also challenged the EU to come forward with a counter proposal. (BBC/Times/Sun)

Former UK Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has refused to rule out a leadership challenge to UK PM May. Furthermore, in an interview with The Sunday Times, Johnson questioned whether UK PM May believes in Brexit and branded her Chequers plan “deranged”. (BBC/Times)

EU’s Chief Negotiator Barnier told Labour leader Corbyn that they believed they might be close to finding agreement with UK PM May, but everyone is needs to act calmly and responsibly if the agreement was to get through parliament. (Guardian)

UK Labour leader Corbyn was told his stance made a no-deal Brexit more likely than not; according to sources in Brussels. Brussels is said to hope for the Tory conference to break the deal deadlock. (Newswires)

UK’s Labour party claims UK PM May’s government is the “most divided ever” as it releases a dossier of over 100 Tory MPs criticising the government or colleagues. (Independent)

UK Brexit Secretary Raab is set to warn that if the EU tries to force the UK into accepting a customs union then it will leave without a deal. (BBC)

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt has warned the EU that it will stir Britain's “Dunkirk spirit” if it tries to force a bad Brexit deal on the UK. (Telegraph)

UK Business Secretary Clark has said there are “grounds for optimism” that UK will strike a Brexit deal with the EU. (Sky News)

Former Brexit Secretary Davis said UK PM May’s advisors fail to grasp the practicalities of the negotiations and have tendencies to believe “exaggerations” from Brussels. He also said he thinks it is 80%-90% likely there will be a Brexit deal. (Telegraph/Sky News)

A Sky Poll revealed that 56% of Britons think Brexit will have a worse outcome than they expected when they voted in the EU referendum. (Sky News)

EU

EU Commissioner Dombrovskis said what emerges so far from discussions in Italy does not seem to be in line with EU fiscal rules, he added it's important to stick to responsible fiscal policy to keep interest rates low. The Dutch PM has also expressed his concerns over the Italian budget plan. (Newswires)

Italian Finance Minister Tria is attempting to head off a confrontation between the EU and Italy that by insisting that the country will reduce public debt despite its plans to increase spending. (FT)

ECB’s Rehn (Neutral) said interest rates will remain at this low at least until summer 2019. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the greenback was quiet amid a lack of participants from China and Hong Kong, while EUR/USD and GBP/USD were little changed throughout the session.

Focus has been on JPY weakness and CAD strength with the latter hitting 4-month highs vs. USD as WSJ reported that US and Canada are close to reaching a deal, ahead of the midnight deadline in Washington. USD/CAD then recuperated off lows on the run-up to the release of the official statement that US, Canada and Mexico reached a trade deal now dubbed USMCA. MXN also strengthened throughout the session with USD/MXN hitting lows of near 18.5400 amid the positive developments towards a trilateral deal. Elsewhere, the JPY hit new 2017 lows against the USD as a mostly disappointing Tankan survey and a downbeat Manufacturing PMI underpinned the pair.

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea’s Foreign Minister announced that North Korea would not take the first steps towards denuclearisation without further guarantees from the US. He also warned of the increasing mistrust between Pyongyang and Washington DC. (Telegraph)

Russian Foreign Affairs Minister Lavrov said everything possible will be done to preserve Iran nuclear deal. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded mixed with WTI and Brent extending on gains towards last week’s highs with traders citing growing concern over oil-related Iranian sanctions driving the prices higher. WTI flirted above USD 73.50/bbl while Brent regained the USD 83.00/bbl handle. Elsewhere, gold was little changed as the yellow metal mirrored the DXY’s miniscule moves, while copper was subdued following a disappointing Chinese Caixin PMI which showed a slowdown in the manufacturing sector.

NHC said Hurricane Rosa (located in the Eastern North Pacific) has weakened to a tropical storm but is still expected to cause flooding rains over portions of North-Western Mexico and the Western US. (Newswires)

US Crude Oil Exports fell to 2.139mln bpd in July (vs. 2.2mln bpd in June). (Newswires)

US

Once again, Bunds were dictating the price action of Treasuries through European trade, with German debt catching a bid as Italian debt was sold; Bunds were also aided by somewhat disappointing data on the inflation front. A mixed/weak set of 0830am EST data helped Treasuries find highs, though highs could not be sustained with equities firming/toying with neutral levels. Reported position squaring was also playing a role in the afternoon, with traders squaring books ahead of month/quarter end. Major curves spreads were modestly wider, except for the 2s5s, which narrowed a touch. * US T-note futures (Z8) settled 1 tick higher at 118-25

subject: US and Canada say in an official statement that they have reached a deal with Mexico
content:
A Senior Trump Administration official said:

  • US President Trump is to sign the new trade agreement at the end of November, which will then be submitted to congress
  • Canada has agreed to eliminate "class 7" milk protein pricing system and increase US access to Canada's dairy market beyond Trans-Pacific partnership levels
  • New trade deal does not make major changes to current Chapter 19 trade dispute settlement mechanism
  • Trade deal with Canada does not affect US steel and aluminium tariffs currently levied on Canada
  • Discussions on Canada steel and aluminium tariffs are separate to NAFTA
  • If Trump imposes auto tariffs, both Mexico and Canada will be accommodated in "side letters" 
  • The name of the new deal is to be called USMCA
